content.AIRMON_USAGE: Usage: airmon [start:stop] [net interface] Example: airmon start wlan0
content.AIRMON_DETAIL:
Used to enable <color=orange>monitor mode</color> on wireless interfaces. 
It may also be used to go back from <color=orange>monitor mode</color> to <color=orange>managed mode</color>. 
Entering the <color=#0FABFFFF>airmon</color> command without parameters will show the interfaces status.
content.AIRMON_HELP: It is the first step to be able to get the connection <color=orange>password</color> of a wifi router. The network card needs to be activated in <color=orange>monitor mode</color>.
content.AIREPLAY_DETAIL: Used to inject frames on wireless interfaces. The primary function is to generate traffic for the later use in <color=#0FABFFFF>aircrack</color> for cracking the router keys.
content.AIREPLAY_HELP: [Usage Details] Once you have selected a network you can launch the command to start capturing the necessary data to crack the password. Example: aireplay -b 14:C7:E5:46:D9:F5 -e corpdevice In case of failure, it will mean that the router is patched against this vulnerability. Once the command is executed, wait for a minimum number of packets, ACKs, to be generated. With a good network power, at least 7,000 packages would be enough. For the low power networks you may need as much as 20k acks Once you have reached the desired number of packets, press Control + C to stop the process and save the information in a text file. This file will be in the same folder where the aireplay command was executed.
content.AIRCRACK_HELP: Use with the file generated by aireplay.
content.NMAP_DETAIL: Scan remote ips to find open ports.
content.SMTPUSERLIST_DETAIL: Displays the user accounts registered on the server where the <color=orange>SMTP</color> service is running. The program also shows if those user accounts have an email account associated with the <color=orange>SMTP</color> server.

content.SSH_USAGE: Usage: ssh [user@password] [ip address] [(opt) port] Example: ssh John@Connor 127.0.0.1 Example: ssh John@Connor 127.0.0.1 22
content.SSH_DETAIL: Access to private servers through a back door.
content.SSH_HELP: Once correctly connected to the remote machine, the user can use the terminal to move through the file system of the remote machine, as well as execute commands and programs that are on that machine. To be able to download files ssh use the command scp -d file. And to upload scp -u file. The scp command can only be used when connected using ssh. [ssh encryption] The ssh servers can encrypt the connections to prevent the real password from being captured by sniffers. To activate encryption, just edit the /server/conf/sshd.conf file and change the enabled_encryption variable to true. In that file you can see the path used by the scripts to encode and decode. This algorithm is the one used by default and can be replaced by any other method. The only requirement is that the encode and decode scripts must have a function called Encode=function(password) and Decode=function(password) respectively. In addition, these functions must return a string. Finally, the scripts must be compiled for the system to work. Here is the source code of the algorithms used by default. [Encode source] Encode = function(password) caesar = function(pass, type) nr = pass.len%10 crypt = function(char, nr, type) if type == "enc" then return char+nr if type == "dec" then return char-nr end function out = [] for i in range(0, pass.len-1) c = pass[i].code if c >= 48 and c <= 57 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 48 then c = c+10 if c > 57 then c = c-10 else if c >= 65 and c <= 90 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 65 then c = c+26 if c > 90 then c = c-26 else if c >= 97 and c <= 122 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 97 then c = c+26 if c > 122 then c = c-26 end if out.push(char(c)) end for return out.join("") end function output = caesar(password, "enc") return output end function [Decode source] Decode = function(password) caesar = function(pass, type) nr = pass.len%10 crypt = function(char, nr, type) if type == "enc" then return char+nr if type == "dec" then return char-nr end function out = [] for i in range(0, pass.len-1) c = pass[i].code if c >= 48 and c <= 57 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 48 then c = c+10 if c > 57 then c = c-10 else if c >= 65 and c <= 90 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 65 then c = c+26 if c > 90 then c = c-26 else if c >= 97 and c <= 122 then c = crypt(c, nr, type) if c < 97 then c = c+26 if c > 122 then c = c-26 end if out.push(char(c)) end for return out.join("") end function output = caesar(password, "dec") return output end function
content.TERMINAL_USAGE: [Basic usage] To move between the terminal folders, use the cd command, for example cd folder. You can use the autocomplete function by pressing the TAB key so that the terminal finishes typing the command. If there is more than one match, a list is displayed. To view the contents of a text file you can use the cat command, for example: cat file.txt. There are certain commands that leave the terminal busy, preventing you from entering new commands until it is finished. To cancel a command press Control+C. [Copy and paste] You have 3 ways to copy and paste in the terminal. You can choose the one that is most comfortable for you. QuickEdit It is the fastest way. Select the text you want to copy in the terminal by clicking with the left mouse button and dragging. Once you have the selected text, press the middle mouse button to paste the selected text. Key shortcut Since Control+C is reserved for canceling active commands, you can copy and paste in the terminal with Control+Shift+C and Control+Shift+V Contextual menu Select the text you want to copy in the terminal by clicking with the left mouse button and dragging. Once the text has been selected, press the right mouse button to show the context menu and press copy. To paste text press the right mouse button anywhere in the terminal window to show the context menu, then select the paste option. [Running Programs] A command can be run from any folder on the terminal if it is in the /bin path or in the /usr/bin path. Therefore it is advisable to move any downloaded program to one of those locations or it can only be executed from the folder where it is.

content.MANUAL_TRACE: [General] When you access a remote computer without authorization it is very likely that you will attract the attention of the system administrator. If it finds the machine that started the hacking, it will inform the authorities. Depending on the type of network you have accessed, administrators can be more or less permissive. A good administrator usually finds suspicious activity where others do not see it or simply ignore it. In any case, it is highly recommended that you delete your tracks once you have finished an intrusion. All computers keep a log of the log in /var/system.log. In it, system events are registered, such as incoming or outgoing connections, deletion of files, etc. [Log file] To open the system.log file you need to use a visual program LogViewer.exe (in future updates there will be a terminal version). To do this from the terminal where you are connected to a remote computer, execute the command LogView.exe. You can open graphic applications from the remote computer. Next, launch the FileExplorer.exe application. Go to the /var folder and double click on the system.log file. It is important to keep in mind that the deletion of the records is only useful when a passive trace occurs. There are two types of traces an administrator can perform: Active trace and Passive trace. [Active Trace] It occurs only when the administrator of a system is logged into the computer you have accessed. The way to stop this tracking if it has already started is to disconnect from the remote machine, at which point the passive trace will begin. System administrators, like any other worker, have a work schedule. It is usually advisable to access remote machines at times when the administrator is not working. To know if an administrator or any other user is present in a system you can use the ps command. If there is a process called dsession it means that the user to whom the process belongs is active on the machine. Programs like AdminMonitor notify you in an automated way when an administrator is present and the approximate time remaining until an active trace reaches you. [Passive Trace] It occurs after a failed active trace, or when the administrator goes to work and checks the logs to find suspicious activity. The records of the systems by which the intruder has been jumping until arriving at the origin are analyzed. It is advisable to break the chain of connections at any point so that the administrator can not reach you. These types of traces are much slower than active traces. [How to avoid being caught] It is important that you remove any traces that may incriminate you in an unauthorized connection. In the current version of the game you just have to delete any entry in the file /var/system.log that is either shell obtained or file deleted along with your IP address. If the AdminMonitor program warns you that a admin has started an active trace against you it is important that you try to delete the indicated entries and disconnect before the end of the countdown. Do not delete the entire log, since inevitably when you disconnect from the machine you will create an entry in the log with your disconnection, creating the file if you had deleted it. If an administrator sees a log file with only a disconnect entry, he will suspect and start the trace against you. [How to avoid being caught] (advanced) Keep in mind that if you connect directly to the victim machine, you will not have much reaction time if an administrator starts tracking you. It is advisable to use at least one computer to connect to the victim. For example, if you have a rented computer, you can connect to it and from there to the victim machine. In that case you are using a bounce to connect to the remote machine. You can use as many computers as you want to create these chains of connections (bounces) until you reach the victim. In this way, the more bounces you use, the administrator who is tracking you more time will spend to reach you. Then to eliminate your traces you can completely delete the file /var/system.log from any machine you have used as a bounce. Or alternatively you can also remove from the log of any bounce the entry that indicates a redirection from one ip to the next bounce.

If these users also have registered an email account in the SMTP server, it will be indicated in the list.

content.MV_DETAIL:
Used to move files between folders.

The path can be absolute or relative.
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF>mv Desktop/file.txt /home/Users/Player/DestFolder</color>

It can also be used to rename files.
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF>mv Desktop/file.txt Desktop/othername.txt</color>
content.CP_DETAIL:
Used to copy files between folders.

The path can be absolute or relative.
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF>cp Desktop/file.txt /home/Users/Player/DestFolder</color>
content.CHMOD_HELP:
The permissions of a file are classified in writing, reading and execution.
These permissions can be defined for the owner of the file, the group to which it belongs and others.
The -R parameter indicates recursion, that is, it is used to apply the permissions to a folder and all the files that are inside.

Examples:

To add write permission for others:
<color=#0FABFFFF>chmod o+w file.txt</color>

To remove the read permission to the group:
<color=#0FABFFFF>chmod g-r file.txt</color>
content.CHMOD_DETAIL: Allows to modify the permissions of a file or folder.

content.FTP_DETAIL: File Transfer Protocol (FTP) is the standard network protocol used for the transfer of computer files between a client and server on a computer network.
content.FTP_HELP:
Since <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> is used for file transfer, it's not possible to execute commands on the remote machine since <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> does not offer a <color=orange>shell</color> unlike <color=#0FABFFFF>ssh</color>.

Once correctly connected to the remote machine, the user can use the terminal to move through the file system using common commands such as <color=#0FABFFFF>cd</color> or <color=#0FABFFFF>ls</color>, but only files that are between the connected machine and the <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> server can be downloaded or uploaded.

To see a list of available commands while connected via <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color>, type <color=orange>help</color> in the terminal.

To be able to download <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> files, use <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>get</color> file</color> command.
To upload files <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>put</color> file</color>.

The <color=#0FABFFFF>get</color> and <color=#0FABFFFF>put</color> commands can only be used when connected via <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color>.
content.MAIL_USAGE: It can be launched from the terminal or the user interface by double clicking on the program.
content.MAIL_DETAIL:
It is the default client used to send and receive emails.

It can also be used as a <color=orange>social engineering</color> tool if it is used well.

When you open the mail client, click on the option to write a new email, next to the subject click the <color=orange>[PF]</color> button. You will see a list of predefined emails that you can use to get useful information.

This list will grow as you increase your experience and reputation in the network.

content.FIRST_STEPS:
If this is your first installation you will have verified that you do not have access to the <color=orange>network</color>, so you will not be able to do much until you get connected.

In the future you will be able to contract your own connection to the <color=orange>network</color> for a monthly amount, but for the moment you will have to access it in another way.

The operating system has a security suit installed by default that can help you connect to the <color=orange>network</color>.

For more information it is recommended that you read the following entries in the manual under the Network <color=orange>commands</color> category in the following order:

<color=#0FABFFFF>1. airmon</color>
<color=#0FABFFFF>2. iwlist</color>
<color=#0FABFFFF>3. aireplay</color>
<color=#0FABFFFF>4. aircrack</color>

To launch <color=orange>commands</color> you need to use the <color=#0FABFFFF>terminal</color>. You will find a shortcut on the desktop.

Once you have access to the <color=orange>network</color> we recommend that you create an <color=#33cccc>email account</color>. Use the <color=orange>browser</color> to find a mail services.
content.IWLIST_HELP: [Usage Details] Once the iwlist command is executed the output will show something similar to this: BSSID PWR ESSID 14:C7:E5:46:D9:F5 65% corpdevice BSSID is the identifier of the device. PWR is the coverage that reaches the Wi-Fi network installed in your PC in a range of 0% to 100%. The higher this number is, the closer your device is to your location and you can capture the packets faster. ESSID is the name of the router access point.
content.SUDO_USAGE: Usage: sudo [opt:-s] [command] Usage: sudo -u [username] Example: sudo rm file.txt
content.SUDO_DETAIL:
It allows users to run programs with administrator security privileges, also known as <color=orange>root</color>.
It can also be used to access as any other user registered on the machine, using the -u parameter.
content.SUDO_HELP:
The <color=#0FABFFFF>sudo</color> command can be executed to obtain <color=orange>root</color> permissions only for the execution of that command.
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF>sudo</color> rm file.txt

Or to login as <color=orange>root</color> user.
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>sudo</color> -s</color>

In both cases, the administrator password will be requested before continuing.

The <color=#0FABFFFF>sudo</color> command also allows access like any other user registered on the machine:
Example: <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>sudo</color> -u</color> john

The user password will be requested before continuing.

content.USERDEL_DETAIL: Utility that is used for deleting user accounts.
content.USERDEL_HELP: If the <color=orange>-r</color> parameter is used in addition to deleting the user from the system, it will also delete the folders and files created under its user folder located in <color=yellow>/home/username</color>.
content.SAVEGAME:
The game is automatically saved in real time in both multiplayer and single player mode, so you do not have to worry about saving the game.

To exit the game open the main menu, located in the upper left corner of the screen, and select the option <color=#0FABFFFF>shutdown</color>. When you start the game you will find everything as you left it.

content.TUTORIAL_START:
Welcome to your new Operating System.

The <color=#33cccc>tutorial</color> will teach you the basics to know how to move around the OS.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_WINDOWS:
The window system is similar to any other operating system.

You can move, minimize, maximize and resize windows using the UI.

You can also create files, delete them, move them and execute programs with the user interface as in any Operating System.

[ACTION] To continue, close this window and then double click on the <color=#0FABFFFF>FileExplorer</color> program on the <color=orange>desktop</color>. [/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM:
It is important that you know how the <color=orange>file system</color> is structured.

It is quite simple: All folders hang from a main folder represented with the <color=yellow>/</color> character and is the first or the highest directory in the hierarchy.

It can be likened to the <color=#33cccc>trunk of a tree</color>, as the starting point where all <color=#33cccc>branches</color> originate from.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM2:
When you open the <color=#0FABFFFF>FileExplorer</color> program by default it opens in the home folder of the user who launched it.

In your case, your user's path is: <color=yellow>[HOME_PATH]</color>

This is the path where your user's configuration files will be saved and where you will normally work.

When a user is created on the machine, their user files will be created automatically under the <color=yellow>/home</color> path.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL:
It's time to go to the <color=#0FABFFFF>Terminal</color>.

At certain moments of the game it will be necessary to execute commands from the terminal to access remote machines or launch tools that do not have a visual variant.

It is easier than it seems to be. 

[ACTION]Open the <color=#0FABFFFF>Terminal</color> program that is on the <color=orange>desktop</color> and press <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL2:
Think of the <color=orange>terminal</color> as a kind of <color=orange>File Explorer</color>.

From the <color=orange>terminal</color> you browse the folders and run programs the same way you do with the browser.

By default, when you open the <color=orange>terminal</color>, you are in the path of your user. 

[ACTION]Type <color=#0FABFFFF>pwd</color> in the <color=orange>terminal</color> and press <color=#33cccc>Enter</color> to launch the command. The command will show you the path you are currently on.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL3: [ACTION]To list the files that are in the folder where you are, use the <color=#0FABFFFF>ls</color> command.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL4:
Now you will learn how to create folders from the <color=orange>terminal</color>.

You can also create folders from the file explorer, but it is important that you learn to do it from the <color=orange>terminal</color> to understand how it works.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL5:
From the <color=orange>terminal</color>, create a folder called <color=#33cccc>test</color> in your <color=yellow>[HOME_PATH]/Desktop</color> folder.

First enter the Desktop folder executing the following command:
[ACTION]<color=#0FABFFFF>cd Desktop</color>[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL6:
Note that in the <color=orange>terminal</color> you can write the complete path of any file. 

For example, you can enter the Desktop folder from anywhere in the <color=orange>terminal</color> by typing the full path:

<color=#0FABFFFF>cd [HOME_PATH]/Desktop</color>

The <color=orange>terminal</color> also accepts relative path.

This applies to any command you use.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL7:
Execute the <color=#0FABFFFF>ls</color> command to see the files that are in the folder.

As you can see, they are the same files that you see on your desktop.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL8:
[ACTION]Now type <color=#0FABFFFF>mkdir test</color> to create the folder.[/ACTION]

You can see the folder created from the <color=orange>file explorer</color> or the <color=orange>desktop</color> itself.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL9: You already know what is necessary to use the <color=#0FABFFFF>terminal</color>, you still have a couple of important things to know, but I'll tell you later.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_WIFI:
As you know a computer without <color=orange>internet</color> access does not have much utility, and at the moment you do not have access to the <color=orange>network</color>.

Your computer is equipped with a wireless <color=orange>network</color> card, if you click on the <color=orange>wifi</color> icon in the top bar, you can see the <color=orange>network</color>s you have at your range.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_WIFI2:
Now you are going to use the equivalent command in the <color=#0FABFFFF>terminal</color>, which will give you some extra information of these networks that you will find useful to crack a password.

Open the <color=#0FABFFFF>terminal</color> and type <color=#0FABFFFF>iwlist eth0</color>

The parameter eth0 refers to your network card. If you had more than one network card they would be named eth1, eth2, etc.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_WIFI3: As you can see after launching the command it shows you the same list of networks as using the user interface, but with some extra information.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_END1: It's time to get access to the network. This part of the tutorial will not be guided, you will have to be able to read the instructions of a series of commands and execute them correctly. The Manual is an essential tool to know in detail how programs found on your computer works. In the Manual you will find examples of the use of commands and programs. It is always a good idea to check it when you have downloaded a new program. [ACTION]To access the network, open the Manual and click on the [First Steps] section to get more information.[/ACTION]
content.RENT_SERVER:
Thank you for your purchase, your server is ready!

Here you have the credentials to access via <color=#0FABFFFF>ssh</color>:

IP: [PUBLIC_IP]
user: root
password: [ROOT_PASSWORD]

[ADD_SERVER_MAP]
content.MISSION_SERVICE_PC_NOT_EXIST:
The IP address you have provided does not belong to any computer.
Make sure the address is correct and belongs to an accessible computer.

You can delete this message.
content.MISSION_SERVICE_WRONG_IP:
The format of the IP address that you have provided is incorrect.
Please try again and make sure you enter the address correctly.

You can delete this message.
content.MISSION_SERVICE_START:
The data you have provided is correct. 
The mission is now active. 

Make sure you do not interrupt access to the machine until the end date.
content.MISSION_SERVICE_FAILED_INI: You have taken too long to configure the server and the client has canceled the job.
content.MISSION_ALREADY_STARTED: The mission was already active. Remember not to interrupt access to the server.
content.NSLOOKUP_DETAIL: It is used to obtain the ip address knowing the name of the web.
content.ERROR_NO_HOME: Error: Can't find your user desktop path: /home/[activeUser]/Desktop This error usually occurs because the user has accidentally changed the name of their user folder under the path /home. Your home path /home/[activeUser]/Desktop has been recreated.
content.MISSION_POLICE_CONTENT: The client wants to modify the information of a police record.
content.MISSION_POLICE_CHANGES: It is necessary that you infiltrate the network to modify the date of certain charges.
content.MISSION_POLICE_REMOVE: It is necessary that you infiltrate in the network to eliminate the complete record of a person.
content.MISSION_POLICE_ADD_CHARGE: You need to infiltrate the network to add a charge to a person's record.
content.MISSION_POLICE_REMOVE_CHARGE: You need to infiltrate the network to remove a charge to a person's record.
content.MISSION_POLICE_MODREG: The client wants to modify the charge of [CRIME] so that the date of the crime is [YEARS] years before it was committed.
content.MISSION_POLICE_DETAIL_REMOVE_CHARGE: The client wants to delete the charge of [CRIME]. To avoid raising suspicion, you only have to eliminate the indicated crime, do not eliminate any other.
content.MISSION_POLICE_DETAIL_ADD_CHARGE: The client wants to add the charge of [CRIME] in the year [YEAR]. To avoid raising suspicion, you only have to add the indicated crime.
content.MISSION_POLICE_DETAIL_DELETE: The client wants to delete the record completely.
content.MISSION_FAILED: You have not completed the order requirements. The job is cancelled.
content.MISSION_DESTROY_PC_CONTENT: The client wants the remote machine to stop working.
content.MISSION_DESTROY_PC: Be careful since the administrator will want to know who was responsible.
content.PASSWD_HELP: To change a password of a user, first "sudo" to the "root" account. Then type, passwd user (where user is the username for the password you are changing)
content.HINT_COMM_NOTFOUND: You may want to launch the command found in: [PATH_COMMAND] To execute it you have to cd in the folder where the command is located. If you want to launch the command from anywhere in the terminal, copy it to the global path in: /bin or /usr/bin
content.WARNING_PASSWORD:
It is not recommended to use any of your real-life passwords in the game, since these passwords can be discovered by other players and are accessible by any administrator of the game server.

It is also not recommended to use any real password in single player mode since the passwords are saved in plain text in the game's installation folder.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM3: [ACTION]Now go to the main folder, the top folder in the file hierarchy and click <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM4:
Here you can see all the folders that hang from the main one. 

At the moment we are only interested in the <color=yellow>/bin</color> folder and the <color=yellow>/usr<color=yellow>/bin</color></color> folder.

[ACTION]Go to the <color=yellow>/bin</color> folder and press <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM5:
By default, the commands used by the terminal are saved in the folder <color=yellow>/bin</color>. We will come back here later.

[ACTION]Now go to the path <color=yellow>/usr<color=yellow>/bin</color></color> and press <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM6:
And here <color=orange>programs</color> that have <color=#33cccc>UI</color> (user interface) are saved by default.

You can run any program by double clicking as in any operating system.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_FILESYSTEM7:
Remember that in the <color=#0FABFFFF>FileExplorer.exe</color> program and on the <color=#0FABFFFF>desktop</color> you can copy files by dragging their icon to the place you want, renaming or deleting files, creating folders, etc.

You can open the <color=orange>contextual menu</color> on a file or folder to see the available actions by clicking the <color=#33cccc>right mouse button</color> on the file.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL10:
If you want you can delete the folder from <color=orange>UI</color> by clicking on the icon with the <color=#33cccc>right mouse button</color> and then select delete.

You can also delete it from the te<color=#0FABFFFF>rm</color>inal by typing the command: <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>rm</color> -r test</color>

Note that the files that you delete from the <color=orange>UI</color> will be moved to the recycle bin, but if you delete files from the te<color=#0FABFFFF>rm</color>inal with the <color=#0FABFFFF>rm</color> command they will be deleted directly without going to the trash.
content.TUTORIAL_RESET:
This option enables the tutorial of the start of the game. It also affects the help windows that appear when you open certain programs for the first time.

The reset button restarts the tutorial and the help windows in the programs are displayed again.
content.TUTORIAL_GIFT:
After having connected for the first time to a Wi-Fi network, the next time you start a new game you will have a file on the desktop called Gift.txt which will give you the password of one of the Wi-Fi networks you have available.

If you deactivate this option you will have to crack a wifi password every time you start a new game or after a Game Over.
content.TUTORIAL_RESET_MISSION: This option resets the first available mission after accessing the network for the first time.
content.CLOSE_PROGRAM_TUTORIAL:
You have a tutorial associated with this window. 

If you close this window the current tutorial will be canceled, but it will start again the next time you open this program.

Do you want to continue?
content.CLOSE_TUTORIAL_WINDOW: Do you want to skip the current tutorial?
content.TUTORIAL_MAIL:
Great! You already have an internet connection and you have received your first email.

But first you need to know a couple of things about the mail program.
content.TUTORIAL_MAIL2:
As in any mail program you can write emails in addition to receiving them. But here you also have some predefined emails that can be very useful.

Click on the email button and click <color=orange>Next</color>.
content.TUTORIAL_MAIL3:
The mail client can be used as a <color=orange>social engineering</color> tool if it is used well.

If you click on the <color=#33cccc>[PF]</color> button next to the subject, you will get a list of predefined emails that you can use to get useful information.

This list will grow as you increase your experience and reputation in the network.

This is all for now. You can close this window.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN:
Your first remote connection!

Before continuing, it is important that you know some details about remote connections.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN2:
Remote connections can only be made through the terminal.

In addition to the <color=#0FABFFFF>ssh</color> command, you will discover other programs that will also allow you to connect remotely to a machine
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN3:
When connected to a machine you can navigate through its file system and run programs as if it were your machine, provided you have the necessary permissions.

Note that you can launch visual programs through the <color=orange>terminal</color> even connected to a remote machine.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN4:
For example, although you can use the scp command to upload and download files from the remote machine, you can also do so using the UI.

[ACTION]To do this, launch the <color=#0FABFFFF>FileExplorer.exe</color> program from the terminal where you are connected to the remote machine and press <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN5:
As you can see, you are browsing through the file system of the remote machine using FileExplorer.

You can copy and paste files between machines using FileExplorer, either by dragging the icons or by using the context menu.

Like FileExplorer.exe, you can launch any program and command that is on the remote machine.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN6: It's a good time to show you how to avoid being caught by the authorities.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL11:
Ok, we are on the path <color=yellow><color=yellow>[HOME_PATH]</color>/Desktop</color>.

Let's go back to the path <color=yellow>[HOME_PATH]</color>.

To go to the upper folder type the command
[ACTION] cd .. [/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL12: You can also return to your <color=yellow>[HOME_PATH]</color> folder from anywhere in the <color=orange>terminal</color> by typing only the <color=#0FABFFFF>cd</color> command without any parameters.
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_TERMINAL13:
And last but not least.

Do you remember the <color=yellow>/bin</color> and <color=yellow>/usr<color=yellow>/bin</color></color> paths?

It is where the commands and programs are stored by default respectively.

You can launch any program that is in these folders from any path where you are in the terminal.

But any command or program that is not in any of these two paths, you will have to locate yourself in that folder to be able to launch it or write the complete or relative route to the program.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN7:
When you access a remote computer without authorization it is very likely that you will attract the attention of the system administrator.

If it finds the machine that started the hacking, it will inform the authorities.
Depending on the type of network you have accessed, administrators can be more or less permissive. 

A good administrator usually finds suspicious activity where others do not see it or simply ignore it.

In any case, it is highly recommended that you delete your tracks once you have finished an intrusion. 
All computers keep a log of the log in <color=yellow>/var/system.log</color>.

In it, system events are registered, such as incoming or outgoing connections, deletion of files, etc.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN8:
To open the <color=orange>system.log</color> file you need to use a visual program <color=#0FABFFFF>LogViewer.exe</color>

To do this, open the <color=orange>system.log</color> file on the remote machine using the FileExplorer program you have connected.

[ACTION]With the FileExplorer connected to the remote machine, go to the <color=yellow>/var</color> folder and double click on the <color=orange>system.log</color> file and click <color=orange>Next</color>.[/ACTION]
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN9: It is important to keep in mind that the deletion of the records is only useful when a passive trace occurs. There are two types of traces an administrator can perform: [Active Trace] and [Passive Trace]. System administrators, like any other worker, have a work schedule. It is usually advisable to access remote machines at times when the administrator is not working. Programs like AdminMonitor notify you in an automated way when an administrator is present and the approximate time remaining until an active trace reaches you. It is highly recommended that you take a look at the Manual. In the Trace System section to know in more depth how the traces work and the different ways to avoid them. For the moment it is enough that you know this way to eliminate your trace.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN10:
If the AdminMonitor program warns you that a admin has started an active trace against you it is important that you try to delete the indicated entries and disconnect before the end of the countdown. 

<color=orange>Do not delete the entire log</color>, since inevitably when you disconnect from the machine you will create an entry in the log with your disconnection, creating the file if you had deleted it.

If an administrator sees a log file with only a disconnect entry, he will suspect and start the trace against you.

This is all for the moment, you can close this window.
content.TUTORIAL_REMOTE_CONN11: It is important that you remove any traces that may incriminate you in an unauthorized connection. In the current version of the game you just have to delete any entry in the file /var/system.log that is either [shell obtained] or [file deleted] along with your IP address.
content.TUTORIAL_QUESTION_RESET:
All programs tips and the initial tutorial will be restarted.

Do you want to continue?
content.TUTORIAL_WELCOME_ACTION: To continue, close this window and then double click on the FileExplorer program on the desktop.
content.TUTORIAL_DISABLED:
The tutorial has been disabled.

You can re-enable it from <color=#33cccc>Menu > Preferences > Tutorial</color>

It is recommended to read the <color=orange>Manual</color> to know how programs and commands work. You can open the <color=orange>Manual</color> from the desktop by double clicking the mouse on its icon.

You can also access the help in <color=#33cccc>Menu > Help</color>
content.TUTORIAL_TERMINAL_QUESTION:
A question before starting.

Do you have experience using the UNIX command terminal?
content.TUTORIAL_PAGE_END2:
You can close this window.
Good luck!
content.LS_USAGE: Usage: ls [opt:-l, -a, -la] [opt: path] It can be called without parameters.
content.LS_DETAIL: Shows the list of files in the current folder
content.LS_HELP:
Alternatively you can use the <color=#0FABFFFF>-l</color> parameters to list the files in detailed mode and <color=#0FABFFFF>-a</color> to show the hidden files.

You can combine the parameters.

Example 1: <color=#0FABFFFF>ls <color=#0FABFFFF>-l</color></color>
Example 2: <color=#0FABFFFF><color=#0FABFFFF>ls <color=#0FABFFFF>-l</color></color>a</color>
content.HARDWARE_INSTALLED:
The hardware will be installed in the next 12 hours.
You will be notified when the job is completed.
content.INVALID_PASS: There has been a problem synchronizing your user with server. If you are accessing from a different computer than you usually use, you must copy the PlayerData file from your other computer to this one. You will find the PlayerData file where you installed the game. If the problem persists, please contact the developer through the Steam or Discord forums.
content.INSTALL_HARDWARE:
The hardware you have purchased is ready to be installed.

Click on the install button to open the hardware installation window.
content.HDD_PERFORMANCE: The hard disk has performance issues, the copy speed may be affected.
content.PSU_LOWPOWER: The power supply can not provide enough power. This can lead to an unstable system.
content.CPU_DAMAGED: The processor is damaged. This can lead to an unstable system.
content.INSTALLED_HARDWARE:
The configuration is correct! 

It is necessary to restart the machine so that our systems install the new hardware.
content.NO_BUY_MORE_HARDWARE: At this time you can not buy more hardware until you receive the order you have on the way.
content.IO_ERROR: I/O error. The process could not be completed. System unstable.
content.NO_RAM_MSG: I can not open the program. There is not enough RAM available. Close some program and try again.
content.RAM_DAMAGED: The memory RAM is damaged. This can lead to an unstable system.
content.MOTHERBOARD_DAMAGED: The motherboard is damaged. This can lead to an unstable system.
content.TUTORIAL_FTP:
Your first FTP remote connection!

Before continuing, it is important that you know some details about ftp connections.
content.TUTORIAL_FTP2:
Remote <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> connections can only be made through the terminal.

You can use other programs to remotely connect as <color=#0FABFFFF>ssh</color>, which allows you to run programs and commands on the remote machine.
content.TUTORIAL_FTP3:
In contrast <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> (File Transfer Protocol) can only be used for file transfer, so you can not execute commands on the remote machine. 

Only the commands available in <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color>.

To see a list of available commands while connected via <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color>, type help in the terminal.

You can find more detailed information about <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color> in the manual.
content.NO_RAM_REMOTE: I can not open the program. There is not enough RAM available on your host machine to load the UI. Close some program and try again.
content.SSH-SERVER_DETAIL: Install an SSH access server on the machine.
content.FTP-SERVER_DETAIL: Install an FTP access server on the machine.
content.HTTP-SERVER_DETAIL: Install an HTTP server on the machine to host web pages.
content.ONLINE_MODE_DESC: Explore the Grey Hack universe and forge your own reputation in a world shared by all players. When you leave the game, the online universe remains actively running 24/7.
content.SINGLEPLAYER_MODE_DESC: You play in a world created on your computer. Unlike Online Mode, when you exit the game in Single Player, the in-game universe stops, and progress resumes only upon your return.
content.EXIT_CONFIRMATION: Are you sure you want to exit?
content.OPTION_UNAVAILABLE: This option is not available in the current version of the game.
content.DELETE_PROGRESS: If you want to delete your current game and start a new one, select one of the following options. This will eliminate your current progress.
content.MISSION_LAN_IP_STUDENTS: The LAN address where the database is located is [IP_SERVER_STUDENTS]. If you can not access directly, you can try to access through a teacher's computer in the local network.
content.BUILD_USAGE: Usage: build [file_source_code] [path_new_program] The paths can be relatives. Example: build helloworld.txt /home/user/Desktop
content.DOC_GENERAL_TYPEOF: [Parameters] [1] any object [Description] Returns a string with the type of the object passed as a parameter. [Example] myvalue = "hello" typeObj = typeof(myvalue) print("Type is: " + typeObj) #Output: Type is: string
content.DOC_GENERAL_GET_ROUTER: [Parameters] [1][opt] string ip_address [Description] Returns the router whose public IP matches, otherwise returns null. If the ip_address parameter is not specified, returns the router to which the computer executing this command is connected.
content.DOC_GENERAL_NSLOOKUP: [Parameters] [1]string web_address [Description] Returns the IP address that is behind the web address that has been provided.
content.DOC_COMPUTER: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an object of type Computer that is the computer that is executing the script.
content.DOC_GENERAL_WHOIS: [Parameters] [1] string ip_address [Description] Shows the administrator information behind the IP provided. [Example] info = whois("125.58.74.52") print(info)
content.DOC_GENERAL_COMMAND_INFO: [Parameters] [1] string key_command [Description] Returns the information of common commands of the Operating System, such as mkdir, whois, etc. [Example] info = command_info("cp_usage") print(info) #Output: Usage: cp [path to file] [path to copy]
content.DOC_SHELL_BUILD: [Parameters] [1] string path_source_code [2] string path_destination_folder [3] [opt] bool allow_import [Description] Compile the source code of the file that is in the provided path, and save the executable in the destination path. The name of the executable is the same as that of the source file without the extension. The provided paths must be absolutes. [Example] get_shell.build("/home/user/myprogram.src", "/home/user/Desktop")
content.DOC_SHELL_LAUNCH: [Parameters] [1] string program_path [2] string program parameters [Description] Launches the command in the provided path. [Example] get_shell.launch("/bin/cat", "/etc/passwd")
content.DOC_GENERAL_FORMAT_COLUMNS: [Parameters] [1] string text [Description] Format the text provided so that it is ordered by columns.
content.DOC_GENERAL_IS_LAN_IP: [Parameters] [1] string ip_address [Description] Returns true if the provided address is local, false otherwise. If the provided IP is not valid, it also returns false.
content.DOC_GENERAL_PARENT_PATH: [Parameters] [1] string path [Description] Returns the path provided without the last element. It does not take into account if the path exists. [Example] newPath = parent_path ("/home/user/Desktop") print ("new path:" + newPath) #Output: new path: /home/user
content.DOC_GENERAL_IS_VALID_IP: [Parameters] [1] string ip_address [Description] Returns true if the provided address is valid, false otherwise.
content.DOC_COMPUTER_PUBLIC_IP: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns the public ip of the router or computer object. [Example] print("Public ip:" + get_router.public_ip) print("Public ip:" + host_computer.public_ip)
content.DOC_GET_COMPUTER: [Parameters] [1] string lan_ip [Description] Returns the computer of the local network whose IP matches the one provided.
content.DOC_GET_COMPUTERS: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an array of all the computers that are active and connected to the router in the local network.
content.DOC_ROUTER_PING_PORT: [Parameters] [1] int port_number [Description] Returns the port object that is behind the port number provided if exists, null otherwise.
content.DOC_ROUTER_PORT_INFO: [Parameters] [1] port portObj [Description] Returns a string with the information of the port that has been provided. The port provided must not belong to another network than this router. [Example] router = get_router ports = router.used_ports for port in ports print("info: " + router.port_info(port)) end for
content.DOC_ROUTER_USED_PORTS: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an array of ports that are being used in this router. [Example] router = get_router ports = router.used_ports for port in ports print("info: " + router.port_info(port)) end for
content.DOC_COMPUTER_GET_PORTS: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an array of active ports on the computer. [Example] router = get_router ports = get_shell.host_computer.get_ports for port in ports print("Info: " + router.port_info(port)) end for
content.DOC_COMPUTER_IS_NETWORK_ACTIVE: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns true if the computer has internet access, false otherwise.
content.DOC_COMPUTER_LOCAL_IP: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the computer or router local ip address. [Example] print( host_computer.local_ip ) print( get_router.local_ip )
content.DOC_COMPUTER_FILE: [Parameters] [1] string path_file [Description] Returns the file located in the given path, relative or absolute. The file returned can be a folder. If the file does not exist, it is returned null. [Example] file = get_shell.host_computer.File("/etc/passwd") if file != null then print(file.content) end if
content.DOC_GENERAL_CURRENT_PATH: [Parameters] None [Description] It returns a string with the path in which the terminal is at the moment of launching the script.
content.DOC_COMPUTER_CREATE_FOLDER: [Parameters] [1] string path [2] string folder_name [Description] Create a folder in the specified path. [Example] get_shell.host_computer.create_folder("/home/user/Desktop", "myfolder")
content.DOC_FILE_COPY: [Parameters] [1] string path [2] string file_new_name [Description] Copy the file to the specified path. [Example] origFile = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user/myfile.txt") origFile.copy("/home/user/Desktop", "copyfile.txt")
content.DOC_FILE_MOVE: [Parameters] [1] string path [2] string file_new_name [Description] Move the file to the specified path. [Example] origFile = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user/myfile.txt") origFile.move("/home/user/Desktop", "movefile.txt")
content.DOC_FILE_RENAME: [Parameters] [1] string new_name [Description] Rename the file with the name provided.
content.DOC_FILE_PATH: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the path of the file.
content.DOC_FILE_GET_CONTENT: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the contents of the text file.
content.DOC_FILE_IS_BINARY: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns true if the file is binary, false otherwise.
content.DOC_FILE_HAS_PERMISSION: [Parameters] [1] string type_perm [Description] Returns true if the user who launches the script has the necessary permissions. The type_perm parameter is used for reading ("r"), writing ("w") and execution ("x") [Example] file = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user/test.txt") if file.has_permission("r") then print(file.content) else print("permission denied") end if
content.DOC_FILE_PARENT: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns the folder that contains this file.
content.DOC_FILE_NAME: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the name of the file.
content.DOC_IS_FOLDER: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns true if the file is a folder, false otherwise.
content.DOC_FILE_DELETE: [Parameters] None [Description] Delete the file. [Example] file = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user/myfile.txt") if file.has_permission("w") then file.delete else print("permission denied") end if
content.DOC_FILE_GET_FOLDERS: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an array of the folders contained in this object. This function is only available if this object is a folder, so it is advisable to first use the is_folder function before calling this method. [Example] parent = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user") if parent.is_folder then folders = parent.get_folders for folder in folders print("Folder name: " + folder.name) end for end if
content.DOC_FILE_GET_FILES: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an array of files (excluded folders) contained in this object. This function is only available if this object is a folder, so it is advisable to first use the is_folder function before calling this method. [Example] parent = get_shell.host_computer.File("/home/user/Desktop") if parent.is_folder then files = parent.get_files for file in files print("File name: " + file.name) end for end if
content.DOC_PORT_GET_LAN_IP: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the local IP address of the computer pointed to by this port.
content.DOC_PORT_IS_CLOSED: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns true if this port is closed, false otherwise.
content.DOC_PORT_PORT_NUMBER: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns an int with the configured port number.
content.DOC_GENERAL_ACTIVE_USER: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with the name of the user who is executing the script.
content.DOC_GENERAL_HOME_DIR: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a string with home folder path of the user who is executing the script. [Example] print("User home path: " + home_dir)
content.DOC_BASICS: [Clean Syntax] Put one statement per line, with no semicolons. Code blocks are delimited by keywords (see below). Indentation doesn't matter (except for readability). Comments begin with //. All variables are local by default. [if / else if / else / end if] Use if blocks to do different things depending on some condition. Include zero or more else if blocks and one optional else block. if 2+2 == 4 then print("math works!") else if pi > 3 then print("pi is tasty") else if "a" < "b" then print("I can sort") else print("last chance") end if [while / end while] Use a while block to loop as long as a condition is true. s = "Spam" while s.len < 50 s = s + ", spam" end while print(s + " and spam!") [for / end for] A for loop can loop over any list, including ones easily created with the range function. for i in range(10, 1) print i + "..." end for print("Liftoff!") [break & continue] The break statement jumps out of a while or for loop. The continue statement jumps to the top of the loop, skipping the rest of the current iteration. [:Numbers:] All numbers are stored in full-precision format. Numbers also represent true (1) and false (0). [Operators] standard math: +, -, *, / mod (remainder): % power: ^ logical operators: and, or, not comparison: ==, !=, >, >=, <, <= [Strings] Text is stored in strings of Unicode characters. Write strings by surrounding them with quotes. If you need to include a quotation mark in the string, write it twice. print("OK, ""Bob"".") [Operators] string concatenation: + replication: * division: / comparison: ==, !=, >, >=, <, <= get character i: [i] get slice from i up to j: [i:j] [Lists] Create a list with square brackets. Then iterate over the list with for, or pull out individual items with a 0-based index in square brackets. A negative index counts from the end. Get a slice (subset) of a list with two indices, separated by a colon. x = [2, 4, 6, 8] x[0] // 2 x[-1] // 8 x[1:3] // [4, 6] x[2]=5 // x now [2,4,5,8] [Operators] list concatenation: + replication: * division: / get/set element i: [i] get slice from i up to j: [i:j] [Maps] A map is a set of values associated with unique keys. Create a map with curly braces; get or set a single value with square brackets. Keys and values may be any type. m = {1:"one", 2:"two"} m[1] // "one" m[2] = "dos" [Operators] map concatenation: + get/set value with key k: [k] get/set value by identifier: .ident [:Functions:] Create a function with function(), including parameters with optional default values. Assign the result to a variable. Invoke by using that variable. Parentheses are needed on the call only when passing arguments. Use @ to reference a function without invoking. triple = function(n=1) return n*3 end function print(triple) // 3 print(triple(5)) // 15 f = @triple print(f(5)) // also 15 [Classes & Objects] Shape = {"sides":0} Square = new Shape Square.sides = 4 x = new Square x.sides // 4 Functions invoked via dot syntax get a self variable that refers to the object they were invoked on. Shape.degrees = function() return 180*(self.sides-2) end function x.degrees // 360 [Base Functions] Numeric abs(x) acos(x) asin(x) atan(x) cos(r) pi round(x,d) rnd rnd(seed) sign(x) sin(r) sqrt(x) str(x) tan(r) char(i) floor(i) String .hasIndex(i) .indexOf(s) .len .val .remove(s) .lower .code .upper .lastIndexOf(i) .trim .replace(s, s) .split(s) List/Map .pull .indexOf(x) .indexes .values .len .sum .push(x) .pop .shuffle .remove(i) .hasIndex(i) range(from, to, step) slice(l, from, to) List-specific .reverse .join(s) Other print(s)

If the library has been included correctly, it will return an object of corresponding type with the library, null otherwise. content.DOC_GENERAL_USER_INPUT: [Parameters] [1] [opt] string promptMsg [2] [opt] bool passwordMode [3] [opt] bool anyKey [Description] It puts the program on hold to receive the user input, which will be processed as a string. If the password mode is activated, the input text will be hidden with asterisks. If the anyKey argument is true, the entered character will be captured without pressing enter. [Example] name = user_input("Type your name: ") pass = user_input("Type your password: ", true) print("Good! your name is " + name +". And your password is " + pass)

By default, if the optional parameter is not passed, the home folder will not be deleted. It is necessary to be root to be able to execute the method. Returns true on success, false otherwise.

content.DOC_METAXPLOIT_LOAD: [Parameters] [1] string lib_path [Description] Load the library in memory and return it as a metalib type if the process was successful.
content.DOC_METAXPLOIT_NET_USE: [Parameters] [1] string ip_address [2] [opt] port [Description] It connects to the specified address and establishes a null session to gain access to a library remotely. This type of attack is only available for services that work remotely. If no port is specified, it will connect directly to the router. If the process has been executed correctly, an object of type net_session will be returned.
content.DOC_METAXPLOIT_SCAN: [Parameters] [1] MetaLib metalib [Description] Analyze the memory areas occupied by the library in search of vulnerabilities. Returns a list with the affected memory zones.
content.DOC_METAXPLOIT_SCAN_ADDRESS: [Parameters] [1] MetaLib metalib [2] string mem_address [Description] It analyzes a specific memory address and shows the vulnerable parts that can be exploited.
content.DOC_METALIB_OVERFLOW: [Parameters] [1] string mem_address [2] string unsec_value [3] [opt] extra_args [Description] Exploits the indicated vulnerability through the buffer overflow method. The object returned can be of various types or even not return anything, so it is advisable to use the typeof method with the object returned. Depending on the result, it may be necessary to pass extra arguments so that the exploit runs correctly, for example in the case of a password change.
content.DOC_METALIB_LIB_NAME: [Parameters] None [Description] Print the name of the library.
content.DOC_METALIB_VERSION: [Parameters] None [Description] Print the version of the library.
content.DOC_NETSESSION_DUMP_LIB: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns the metalib associated with the remote service. For example, connecting to a computer with the ssh service will return a metalib libssh object. In the case of connecting to a router, it returns a metalib kernel_router object.
content.DOC_ROUTER_DEVICE_PORTS: [Parameters] [1] string ip_address [Description] Takes a LAN IP address and returns a list with open ports accessible in the network.
content.DOC_ROUTER_DEVICES_LAN_IP: [Parameters] None [Description] Returns a list with any computer whose gateway is the current device with the ips of the routers and switches that it can reach with a ping. Some of the returned addresses could be behind a firewall
content.DOC_INJECT_LIB: [Parameters] file library [Description] Injects the local library passed as a parameter to the victim's computer, if the library through which the null connection is being made has a vulnerability that allows it. This is useful to be able to use include_lib from a library that does not physically exist on the victim's computer, such as metaxploit.so. If the injection is done correctly, the terminal will be busy keeping the library in memory of the victim's computer. To stop the process, press the key combination Ctrl+C on the terminal. [Example] metaxploit = include("metaxploit") library = get_shell.host_computer.File("/lib/metaxploit.so") null_session = metaxploit.net_use( "50.85.78.47", 22 ) null_session.inject_lib(library)

content.ING_FORCE_ONLINE:
Hello <NAME>.
I am the administrator <NAME_ADMIN> of your workstation in <COMPANY_NAME>.

I am carrying out maintenance tasks and an error has occurred in your account.
I need you to connect as soon as possible to your workstation, so I can check that everything is correct.

Please, let me know when you are ready.
Regards.
content.ING_WRONG_COMPANY: Ok, this is weird, I do not work there ...
content.ING_USER_CONNECTED:
I just entered to the server with my user.
I will be aware of the mail in case you need something else.
content.ING_FORCE_ONLINE_ADMIN:
Hello <NAME_ADMIN>.
I'm <NAME>, I work with you on <COMPANY_NAME>.

I have to finish some pending tasks remotely, but when I enter the credentials of my account, the system alerts me that someone has tried to enter into my account in an unauthorized way.

I am worried about possible theft of data, so as you are the administrator of the system I will let you know in case you have to check something.
Thanks for your time.
content.ING_WRONG_ADMIN:
I'm sorry, it seems you're wrong, I'm not the administrator of the system.
I guess who you're looking for is <NAME_ADMIN>
Good luck, see you at work.
content.ING_ADMIN_CONNECTED: Thanks for the warning, I will connect and check that everything is fine.
content.ING_ADMIN_ALREADY_CONNECTED: Thanks for the warning, I was already connected, I'll check that everything is fine.
content.ING_INFO_SYSTEM:
Hey!

Sorry to bother you, I'm <NAME>, your co-worker :)

Can you help me?
I do not know what I've done, but I've accidentally deleted a library from my computer and I do not want to bother the administrator. The last time he did not take it very well.

I guess I'm not very good with computers :D

Would you mind telling me which version of the library <LIB_NAME> you have installed?

I have understood that the same versions are used in all machines, so I can restore the version I had without having to tell the administrator.
Thank you!
content.ING_ADMIN_SUSP:
This is very strange, I am the system administrator and I do not remember that you have deleted any library before.
Who you really are?
content.ING_SAME_NAME: I do not understand anything ... That's me! I think I should tell someone about this.
content.ING_NO_INFO: I'm sorry, I can not send you that information.
content.ING_WRONG_LIB:
Oops, it seems like something strange happens to my library. It seems that someone has ...modified it?

Ask me again in a little while to see if I have solved it by then.
content.ING_LIB_VERSION_MAIL:
Do not worry, there is no problem.
The <LIB_NAME> version that I have installed is: <LIB_VERSION>
content.ING_LIB_NOT_FOUND: I'm sorry, but I do not have that library installed on my computer.

content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS1:
In Hackshops there are usually jobs available.

In addition to the tools and jobs, some hackers publish their exploits on these pages.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS2:
The main services and programs of a computer depend on the libraries they have installed. For example, an <color=orange>ssh</color> server has the <color=orange>lib<color=orange>ssh</color>.so</color> library installed in the system.

These libraries usually have vulnerabilities that can be attacked to gain access to the machine.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS3:
As these <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> are exploited, <color=#33cccc>library</color> developers will discover and patch them, publishing updates so that any system administrator can patch it.

Due to the nature of the software development, <color=#33cccc>library</color> updates will bring new errors and <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> that users may exploit.

Therefore some versions will be safer than others, however the latest version is not necessarily the safest.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS4:
To search for <color=orange>exploits</color> in the store, you have to select the <color=#33cccc>library</color> and the version you want to hack.

After pressing search, a list will appear with the <color=orange>exploits</color> published at that time.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS5:
You can classify the exploits into two classes: <color=orange>Local use</color> and <color=orange>Remote use</color>

<color=orange>Remote exploits</color> are those that can be run from any computer to attack any remote machine connected to the internet.

This type of vulnerability is reserved for libraries of programs that have services open to the outside, such as <color=#0FABFFFF>ssh</color>, <color=#0FABFFFF>ftp</color>, <color=#0FABFFFF>smtp</color> and <color=#0FABFFFF>sql</color>

In the description of the exploit in the store, it is detailed what type of <color=orange>permissions</color> are obtained if the exploit is executed successfully.

For example, if executing an exploit gives you access to a terminal on the victim's computer, depending on the type of exploit you will have <color=#33cccc>root</color>, <color=#33cccc>guest</color> or <color=#33cccc>common user</color> access on the machine.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS6:
The <color=orange>exploits</color> of <color=orange>Local use</color> can only be executed from the victim's machine since they use <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> in the libraries of the OS such as, <color=#0FABFFFF>init.so</color>, <color=#0FABFFFF>kernel_module.so</color> and <color=#0FABFFFF>net.so</color> that do not have direct access to the outside.

This means that in order to successfully run a local exploit, you first need to have gained access, at least as a <color=#33cccc>guest</color>, to the remote machine.

Usually, this type of <color=orange>exploits</color> are used to escalate privileges on the remote machine. For example if you have access to the victim's machine but only with the <color=#33cccc>guest</color> account you will not be able to do much.

But you can upload a local exploit to the victim's machine that gives you <color=#33cccc>root</color> privileges.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS7:
Since some <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> require that specific behaviours occur in the program in order to exploit it, some exploits need certain requirements to be met in order to run successfully.

It is advisable to save some money and hire a rented server, where you can do your tests and prepare the next attack in private without the danger of alerting the authorities.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS8: When you select an exploit to buy it, you have the option to download the source code or the compiled version. If you want to download the exploit source code to review and compile it yourself with the CodeEditor, check the "Source code version" box. If instead you want to download the exploit ready to be used in the Terminal, leave the box unchecked.
content.TUTORIAL_EXPLOITS9:
Libraries often have many more hidden <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> than those found in <color=orange>exploits</color> published in Hackshops.
These <color=#33cccc>vulnerabilities</color> can be scanned with the <color=#0FABFFFF>scanlib</color> tool to program your own <color=orange>exploits</color>.

If you are interested in programming, check the "scripting" section in the <color=#0FABFFFF>Manual</color> for more information.

This is all for now, you can close this window.
content.MANUAL_EXPLOITS: [Libraries & Exploits] The main services and programs of a computer depend on the libraries they have installed. For example, an ssh server has the libssh.so library installed in the system. These libraries usually have vulnerabilities that can be attacked to gain access to the machine. As these vulnerabilities are exploited, library developers will discover and patch them, publishing updates so that any system administrator can patch it. Due to the nature of the software development, library updates will bring new errors and vulnerabilities that users may exploit. Therefore some versions will be safer than others, although not necessarily the latest version must be the safest. You can classify the exploits into two classes: [Remote use] Remote exploits are those that can be run from any computer to attack any remote machine connected to the internet. This type of vulnerability is reserved for libraries of programs that have services open to the outside, such as ssh, ftp, smtp and sql In the description of the exploit in the store, it is detailed what type of permissions are obtained if the exploit is executed successfully. For example, if executing an exploit gives you access to a terminal on the victim's computer, depending on the type of exploit you will have root, guest or common user access on the machine. [Local use] The exploits of local use can only be executed from the victim's machine since they use vulnerabilities in the libraries of the OS such as, init.so, kernel_module.so and net.so that do not have direct access to the outside. This means that in order to successfully run a local exploit, you first need to have gained access, at least as a guest, to the remote machine. Usually, this type of exploits are used to escalate privileges on the remote machine. For example if you have access to the victim's machine but only with the guest account you will not be able to do much. But you can upload a local exploit to the victim's machine that gives you root privileges. [Requirements] Since some vulnerabilities require that specific behaviours occur in the program in order to exploit it, some exploits need certain requirements to be met in order to run successfully. It is advisable to save some money and hire a rented server, where you can do your tests and prepare the next attack in private without the danger of alerting the authorities.

All available terminal programs such as <color=#0FABFFFF>ls</color>, <color=#0FABFFFF>cat</color>, <color=#0FABFFFF>mv</color>, etc. are programmed with the GreyScript language and compiled into executables to be used in the terminal.

content.SCANLAN: ScanLan is a powerful tool that visually shows the details of the network you are connecting to, allowing you to see how the network is structured, as well as all the IP addresses available on the LAN. Although a network is very large does not mean that it has more security than a small network. The security of the LAN depends on the configuration of it. [Rules] In the network you can find, in addition to computers, routers, switches and hubs. The ping simulation action will help you know which parts of the network you can reach from the current machine. The ping command is also available from the terminal. You can ping any computer on the network whose gateway is a router. If the gateway is a switch or another computer, you can only ping if you are on the same subnet. You can also ping between devices directly like routers or switches. [Hardware Firewall] A firewall configured on a router or switch will prevent any connection from passing if there is a DENY rule that affects the connection. This applies to any firewall that is between the source and the destination. The ALLOW rule takes precedence over the DENY rule, so even though a firewall has a DENY rule of any address and any port configured, it will let through the connection that matches the ALLOW rule, if it exists. The ping command is not blocked by the firewall, so you can know if you can reach a machine in the event that there was no firewall preventing it. [Hubs] The hubs connect to the devices exclusively physically, therefore the hubs do not have an IP address, since they serve to propagate and organize the connections to the devices connected to them. But hubs are more insecure than switches or routers against sniffers. If a sniffer is listening on a computer that is connected to a hub, it will receive network packets from any other device that is connected to that same hub. [Lan Routers] Within the local network, some routers may have the wifi module activated, allowing you to connect to other machines wirelessly within the network. These networks are not listed in the iwlist command since they are not public access connections. The bssid and essid information can be found in ScanLan or through the scripting methods router.bssid_name and router.essid_name. [Switches] The switches are very similar to routers, except that they do not have a Wi-Fi module or portforwarding configuration. Furthermore, unlike routers, they do not route connections to connected computers, so computers can only be accessed behind a switch if you are on the same subnet.

It is recommended that you copy the <color=#0FABFFFF>ScanLan</color> program on the remote machine and run it.
<color=#0FABFFFF>ScanLan</color> is a powerful program that shows you the <color=orange>net</color>work configuration in which the computer is located.

It is especially useful to solve the <color=#33cccc>missions</color> and know which is the victim's machine according to its <color=#33cccc>local address</color>, data that is indicated in the details of the <color=#33cccc>missions</color>.

Keep in mind that when you scan a public address with <color=#0FABFFFF>nmap</color>, it may not show you all the computers on the <color=orange>LAN</color> that have active services, since some computers will not have the port configu<color=orange>red</color> on the router and therefore will not be visible from the outside.

To access these computers, you will first have to access some other machine that has a port open to the outside, or gain a <color=orange>shell</color> access to the router, and from there get to the machine on the <color=orange>LAN</color>.

You can see more details about <color=#0FABFFFF>ScanLan</color> in the <color=#0FABFFFF>Manual</color>.

content.FILE_LORE_1:
In 1972, the UNIX operating system was rewritten in the programming language C, opening the possibility for other programmers to create their own operating system variants. 

During the following years different companies bought licenses in order to distribute their own versions of the operating system. Despite the great popularity of Linux after its creation in 1992, and despite it being open source, it was eventually surpassed by a similar operating system with certain peculiarities.

In 1994 the company Neurobox published its closed source operating system called Ellipse along with an SDK. To date, the names of the programmers behind the project have not been made public. Although the system was initially derived from UNIX, the changes to the source were so substantial that it is now considered a system similar to UNIX, rather than a branch of it.
content.FILE_LORE_02:
Last Thursday night, the murder of Jessie Rees, a computer programmer linked to the development of the popular Ellipse operating system, was reported. 

Although Neurobox never made the names of the people involved public, police investigators suspects that Jessie Rees was affiliated with the company for several years. 

The police are not sharing any other details at this time, but this investigation could potentially expose new information about this secretive company and its popular operating system.
content.FILE_LORE_03:
Every time Jessie Rees is talked about, more questions arise about what really happened.

Neurobox quickly dissociated itself from the problem, police said that after a "thorough" investigation nothing had been found that could link the company to the death of Jessie Rees. This was only two days after.
The case was eventually closed as a suicide, although there was some evidence that did not fit, such as that the handwriting on the note did not correspond to Rees' handwriting, as well as the glass that had recently been replaced in the front door.

He was hired by Neurobox and moved into the facilities they have available to employees. According to some documents found in Rees' house, this seems to have been an essential requirement to be able to work in the company.

As it was later revealed, Rees had been one of the engineers in charge of designing the Ellipse kernel, but certain problems with the company, the details of which have not been disclosed, led to his dismissal shortly before Ellipse was released to the public.
content.FILE_LORE_04: Report Test number 2147 - Qlab 12 After solving the refrigeration problem, an average fidelity of 99.996% has been achieved. It is expected that we reach an even greater average in the coming months. This can leave any encryption and security model obsolete in a matter of weeks, including ours. We are not prepared to open the system and I will insist again to keep these tests in a private environment until we have a secure migration plan.
content.FILE_LORE_05: Report Test number 3542 - QLab 04 The simulations have been impressive. Julia's idea worked to perfection, and we have been able to recreate areas outside the field of vision up to several kilometers with 99.78% efficiency. I know this comes out of the initial goal we had on the project, but I think it would be interesting to see how far we can go. I understand the ethical problems that this presents but we can not ignore what we just got. We are waiting for confirmation to continue with the tests.

content.FILE_LORE_06:
Ellipse was conceived to mainly be used in the corporate sphere, and its strengths were security and portability since it was possible to install the system in different architectures with few changes to the code. To achieve this, the whole system was rewritten in a programming language called Greyscript along with its own closed source compiler. Its peculiar implementation made it really difficult to infect or exploit, in part because nobody managed to create a reliable decompiler for Greyscript. 

In a cryptic message released on the web in 1996, the company announced that Ellipse where to be made available for both personal and commercial use completely free without any licensing. The secrecy surrounding Neurobox along with several cryptic messages published by the company, has spawned numerous theories about the companys origin and agenda while also boosting the popularity of the operating system.
content.FILE_LORE_07:
In 1998 the first major vulnerability in Ellipse was discovered, this vulnerability had been exploited for months until it was discovered, which led to harsh criticism of the company. Their response was the last public message by the company to date: 

Everything under control

Less than 24 hours later a patch was released that fixed the vulnerability. Since then, new vulnerabilities keep appearing, several of which have been connected to corporate espionage and bank heists among other things. To this day the company is stuck in a perpetual cycle of finding and patching these never-ending flaws.

One popular theory is that Neurobox themselves are behind the security flaws, but what they would have to gain from doing this and why they continue to patch their system if that were the case, remains unclear. Meanwhile, the many years of silence from Neurobox since the hacking surge began, continue to inspire new conspiracy theories about the company.
